column12: Longer description of our involvement and/or our process (1-3 paragraphs)

column9: "Frederic Church’s Ombra: Architecture in Conversation with Nature” showcases multimedia design concepts and installations, developed by leading architects and select artists.  As Guest Curator, Barry Bergdoll (of Columbia University and the Museum of Modern Art) invited a group of today’s most exploratory architects to respond to the transitional outdoor rooms at Olana that are so essential to the original 19th century design of Olana’s Main House. These architects were asked to examine assumptions about the relationship of architecture and landscape at Olana, as well as to explore the Main House’s transition to the surrounding natural environment, particularly in our time of climactic and environmental change. Agile Lens was brought on by Sage & Coome for the digital side of their contribution.
column12: Built an iOS AR app for Sage and Coombe Architects to locate their design work (alongside that of artist Chris Doyle) as part of an architectural exhibition. Then provided training for how to build similar apps on their own for future projects.

column9: Toward the finalization of the design, optimized FXCollaborative’s Revit model to provide a photoreal VR tour of Liberty Island with their intervention in place. Careful attention was paid to landscaping features and ensuring the site looked as excellent as possible while maintaining a 90 FPS playback rate.

Agile Lens led development for Bravo Media of a GearVR and browser-based experience to determine optimal locations for architectural projection to achieve a seamless stained-glass effect. This was per Stephen Colbert’s request with a tight deadline before beginning his tenure on The Late Show, and the app needed to help save time in the planning process. The virtual projectors could be spawned, aimed with headpose, driven around the grid, and even have their throw distance adjusted as needed.

Agile Lens periodically created custom AR and VR experiences throughout the design process for Diller Scofidio + Renfro and Fisher Dachs Associates. Example use cases include parametric design options for maximizing seat count and a specialty equipment ‘clearance checker.’

column1: Rice University Music and Performing Arts Center
column12: RUMPAC will house a three-tiered, 600-seat, European-style opera theatre with an orchestra pit for 70 musicians. “The opera house is a visual overture to prepare the audience to enter into the magical world conjured by the music, the story and the theatrical setting of the opera,” said architect Allan Greenberg. “It facilitates a journey into the mind of the composer, in which the human voice gives breath to a living fantasy.” Agile Lens has utilized virtual reality on this project from the earliest concept studies all the way through its now completed design (the project is currently under construction). This constantly updated VR model allowed the unique opportunity to evaluate the design at different stages, all while bearing in mind the human-scale experience of it. In concept design, the team utilized VR sketches and diagrammatic spatial models to determine the strongest overall direction in which to proceed. As the design developed, further options were built into the custom VR experience to determine ideal locations for aisles, seats, railings, catwalks, and lights. As the project neared completion, Agile Lens moved the project from the Unity3D visualization engine to Unreal Engine in order to better serve the photorealistic needs of the lighting and materials. In 2018 their work was a featured case study on Unreal Engine’s website.

When Intel® set out to showcase the power of the Intel® Core™ i9 processor for a virtual reality project, they wanted to go big. As in, arena big. Not just with the structure itself, but with its most striking feature - the thousands of enthusiastic fans inside it. To show how its processors could handle such a computationally-intensive project, Intel commissioned Project Arena, a large virtual facility complete with a playing area, arena seating, lobby, and food court. The experience also includes thousands of virtual 3D fans who not only walk, sit, and move around like a real crowd, but also stand up and cheer at the click of a button. Beyond that, you can even pick a view you enjoy and with the click of a button, snap a beautiful V-Ray render. Agile Lens was brought on to lead the development of this one-of-a-kind VR experience. Working in collaboration with The Glimpse Group, Octopus, Supersymmetric, and HOK (who provided their 3D model of State Farm Arena), the project continuously evolved to accomodate innovative new possibilities, all the while keeping expectations in line with the capabilities of the target technology. The result is a powerful showcase of virtual reality at its most epic.
column15: The Glimpse Group, Octopus, Supersymmetric, HOK

column8: High Fidelity, Double Eye Productions, Cinema360
column9: In partnership with High Fidelity, Agile Lens produced and performed some short-form improv shows and improv workshops on their social VR platform with 6 actors sharing 3 headsets. Shows were performed for virtual and in-person audiences.
column12: In a research and development initiative that fused digital and physical environments, the project, Alive in Plasticland, investigated advancements in the realm of live entertainment through virtual reality. A team of seven professional improvisers from New York City showcased short-form improvisational theater simultaneously to an online virtual audience and a live audience. This dual-audience format was facilitated using three HTC Vive headsets and High Fidelity’s social VR platform, which allowed for innovative use of virtual avatars and a seamless integration of virtual and real-world elements. The setup included live broadcast audio and a virtual camera system that projected the virtual theater experience into the physical theater, and vice versa, enriching the interactive experience for all attendees. Additionally, the project team conducted three improvisational workshops within the same VR platform and environment.

column7: Kent Bye's Podcast Voices of VR Episode #806
column9: A tabletop theater volcap/mocap study for the TCG conference about the kind of guy who, when he walks into a room, everybody notices him.
column12:
This tabletop performance experiment was created for the 2019 Theatre Communications Group National Conference in order to demonstrate to theatre-makers some pros and cons of volumetric capture versus motion capture.

An example: volcap looks more like that actual performer but is more 'baked,' while mocap has less realism but also allows for more post-production and real-time interactivity, such as always having a character look at you.

Additionally, we wanted to combat the perception that producing such an experience is prohibitively expensive, as we created this on minimal budget using  consumer-level technology.
column14: Depthkit, Unity, Microsoft Azure Kinect, Vive Trackers

column6: Winner, Most Innovative Immersive Experience Award, NBFF; Winner, Audience Live Poll Prize, NYCMedia Lab Expo; Nominee, Best Art or Film, AWE Auggie Awards; Finalist, Cannes XR Development Showcase; Recipient of the Wassaic Haunted Mill Residency (2022)
column9: Ghosted is an interactive augmented reality performance piece, featuring volumetrically captured actors appearing across a table from the user in a simulated dating simulator -- for ghosts!
column12:
An open commission by the North Bend Film Festival, Ghosted was designed from the start to use the limitations of the Magic Leap One headset and low-budget volumetric capture from one Azure Kinect by making the subjects of the piece ghosts who remain seated across the table from you. The limited mobility is organic to the setting (a speed-dating scenario) and also keeps the AR objects well within the headset's field of view. It also allowed us to use single-angle volumetric shots, as the user would not be able to see the back half of the subjects anyway. 
We brought in collaborating artists from the NYC comedy and theater scene, compiled the scripts over the course of a month, and then shot each of the 17 vignettes over the course of a week. Those assets were assembled in to a functional app within another 6 weeks.
column14: Unreal Engine, Depthkit, Azure Kinect Camera, Adobe Premiere Pro

column9: In July 2020, a group of theater and XR creators joined forces to experiment with live theater in open source, browser-based VR (on Mozilla Hubs). Two months later they presented the one act play, Jettison, for live virtual audiences at The Here Festival.
column12: For Jettison and its revival in the first On Board XR Festival, our producing team handled general management tasks for the production as well as heading up design, house management and stage management, in both systems and operation.

column8: Originally produced in collaboration with Actors Theatre of Louisville
column9: A Christmas Carol VR is a live, real-time immersive adaptation of Dickens' classic, blending immersive theater with cutting-edge technology. Live actors with facial and motion capture perform on the streets of a virtual Victorian London.
column12: Initially, we partnered with Actors Theater of Louisville for their annual in-person production of A Christmas Carol in 2021. Their new artistic director, Robert Barry Fleming, had seen our presentation of That Kind of Guy at the TCG Conference earlier in the year, and wanted to engage us to help create and integrate digital characters and environments in to their live show. In years since, ATL gave us their blessing to remount it annually however we'd like, and it has become a yearly R&D tradition for us. Each year we set out to try out new production systems, from distribution and ticket management to motion capture solutions and actor/audience interaction methods.

column9: This 5,300 square foot space allows guests to virtually experience what $300 million worth of amenities and shared facilities will feel like at Four Seasons Private Residences. Guests can walk freely and wirelessly around an 82 x 65-foot space and feel like they are walking around a finished residence, the lake clubhouse, indoor sports club, private restaurant, and theater. The experience ends with guests walking into a virtual 96-seat theater and then sitting in four real theater seats.
column12: Agile Lens worked in the development and production phases of this project; we optimized the levels that Pureblink built from DBox's renders, and assembled the software experience to navigate between those levels. We also led the setup and implementation of the holodeck itself, working with the client to develop the entire guest experience from entering the holodeck through the virtual tour. We staffed and managed the first 6 months of operation and managed the operations handoff to a local team.
column14: Unreal Engine, Optitrack system, Motive, Antilatency

column5: Dell Technologies World in Las Vegas
column9: We were excited for Fair Worlds to bring us on to this project for Dell Technologies, which through a central narrative of a cybersecurity booth that's been hacked, walked users through the central tenets of Dell's Cybersecurity offerings.
column12: For this project, we helped with the motion capture and metahuman pipelines, including directing the actors in mocap sessions and getting the mocap software integrated to their Unreal project.

column9: Agile Lens developed an immersive VR car showroom experience with an AI car salesman powered by inworld.ai and vehicle customization, showcasing Vodafone's DAB platform for London Tech Week.

“La Pasión XR" takes guests on an ephemeral, audio-reactive journey through the Gateway Chamber Orchestra’s performance of Osvaldo Golijov's La Pasion según San Marcos. Guests begin downstage in a point cloud scan of the concert hall. There is a soft hum from instruments and music stands dissolving in and out of existence, and guests are presented with a menu for selecting an experience mode, viewing controls and credits. They can freely navigate the theater in their VR headset using teleportation, smooth locomotion and snap rotation. Experience options include a volumetric highlight sequence of the concert and two full featured movements to explore, each with bonus 360 video content and more.

Body of Mine is an award-winning, full-body VR experience that invites you to inhabit the body of another gender and discover stories from transgender individuals. Combining body, face, and eye tracking with personal interviews of transgender individuals, the experimental storytelling experience allows you to hear, discover, and experience stories of gender dysphoria and euphoria. Winner of the Producers Guild Innovation Award, and with accolades from BAFTA, SXSW, and Games for Change, Body of Mine “breaks through a psychological barrier that few pieces of media ever have” (WIRED), taking you on a profound journey of what it means to be a human being.
column12: We were excited to join up with KOST to help them with not just a port of Body of Mine for the Meta Quest, but an optimization overhaul and adding new, community-focused features including an improved navigation system and the ability for users to upload their own stories.
